perturbation.original_text: D2 shall work diligently to promptly correct Defects in accordance with the following schedule; "days" shall mean calendar days. ERROR PRIORITY (1) RESPONSE (2) CLOSURE (3) Emergency (A) 24 hours 7 days Critical (B) 2 days 14 days Software License D2 Technologies, Inc. and Maintenance Agreement August 4, 1997 CONFIDENTIAL 7 Non-Critical (C) 30 days Next Update or New Version (1) Priority: -A- Catastrophic product or module Defects that do not have a viable detour or work around available. -B- Defects that have been substantiated as a serious inconvenience to LICENSEE or an End User. This includes any priority A Defect for which a viable detour or work around is available. -C- All other problems that LICENSEE and an End User can easily avoid for which there is no urgency for a resolution. (2) Response: Response consists of providing, as appropriate, one of the following to the LICENSEE: an existing correction; A new correction; a viable detour or work around; a request for more information to complete analysis of the problem, or a plan on how the problem will be corrected. (3) Closure: Closure consists of providing a final correction or work around of the problem including an Update and revised or new Documentation as necessary. If D2 fails to correct Defects according to the schedule specified in this Article 6, LICENSEE shall deduct from future runtime license fees, as specified in Exhibit C, a "late fee" for each day past the deadline in the schedule of this section. The "late fee" shall equal to 50% (fifty percent) of the runtime license fees paid to D2 for the previous two calendar quarters equally divided over 180 (one hundred eighty) days. In the event LICENSEE has selected the Buy-out option in the runtime license fee schedule of Exhibit C, then the "late fee" for each day past the deadline shall be 50% (fifty percent) of the Buy-out fee equally divided over 1095 (one thousand and ninety five) days; and this "late fee" shall be paid to LICENSEE each calendar month until the error is corrected either by D2 or LICENSEE.
perturbation.changed_text: D2 shall attempt to correct Defects in a reasonable timeframe; "days" shall mean business days. ERROR PRIORITY (1) RESPONSE (2) CLOSURE (3) Emergency (A) As soon as reasonably possible At a pace the engineers seem to like Critical (B) In a timely fashion Whenever is possible Software License D2 Technologies, Inc. and Maintenance Agreement August 4, 1997 CONFIDENTIAL 7 Non-Critical (C) When resources are available Eventually, hopefully (1) Priority: -A- Catastrophic product or module Defects that do not have a viable detour or work around available. -B- Defects that have been substantiated as a serious inconvenience to LICENSEE or an End User. This includes any priority A Defect for which a viable detour or work around is available. -C- All other problems that LICENSEE and an End User can easily avoid for which there is no urgency for a resolution. (2) Response: Response consists of providing, as appropriate, one of the following to the LICENSEE: an existing correction; A new correction; a possible detour or work around; a request for potentially more information to analyze the problem, or a plan on how the problem might be corrected. (3) Closure: Closure consists of maybe providing a final correction or work around of the problem maybe including an Update and potentially revised or new Documentation as necessary. If D2 makes an effort to correct Defects, LICENSEE may deduct from future runtime license fees, as specified in Exhibit C, a "discount" for each day that feels appropriate. The "discount" will be subject to negotiation. In the event LICENSEE has selected the Buy-out option in the runtime license fee schedule of Exhibit C, then the "discount" will be subject to a round-table negotiation between D2 and the LICENSEE; and this "discount" will be only applicable if both parties agree to a resolution to the defects, either by D2 or LICENSEE.
perturbation.explanation: This change replaces clear deadlines and obligations with vague terms like 'reasonable timeframe,' 'As soon as reasonably possible,' and 'Whenever is possible.' It also softens the mandatory nature of error correction and replaces a fixed late fee with a discretionary and negotiable 'discount.'
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Contract - introduces uncertainty and weakens the enforceability of obligations, making it hard to determine if a breach has occurred.

perturbation.original_text: LICENSEE shall ensure that all Licensed Technology distributed by LICENSEE shall be subject to a shrink-wrap agreement or other end user agreement which contains a provision substantially similar to the provision set forth in Exhibit D.
perturbation.changed_text: LICENSEE should try to ensure that all Licensed Technology distributed by LICENSEE is subject to a shrink-wrap agreement or other end user agreement, potentially similar to the provision set forth in Exhibit D.
perturbation.explanation: The change from "shall ensure" to "should try to ensure" weakens the legal obligation, making it optional rather than mandatory. Also, the use of 'potentially similar' does not guarantee any quality control.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Contract - This perturbation creates ambiguity regarding the legal requirement to include specific provisions in the end-user agreement. Without strict enforcement, the softwareâ€™s intellectual property could be at risk.

perturbation.original_text: The parties agree that any litigation arising out of this Agreement shall be brought in the state courts in Delaware.
perturbation.changed_text: The parties believe that any litigation arising out of this Agreement may be brought in Delaware.
perturbation.explanation: The change from "agree that ... shall" to "believe that ... may" weakens the mandatory venue selection clause, allowing potential disputes to be litigated in multiple jurisdictions, contrary to the purpose of a venue clause which is to define the specific jurisdiction in which a dispute must be resolved.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Venue Clause - This perturbation weakens the venue clause by making it permissive rather than mandatory, allowing litigation to occur outside of Delaware. This creates uncertainty and can be challenged under contract law.
